channel.title: Comments on: Database Mail maintenance in SQL Server
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
Thomas, you don’t have the @ sign before d

DECLARE @d DATETIME

SET @d = DATEADD(dd, -14, GETDATE())

EXEC msdb.dbo.sysmail_delete_log_sp @logged_before = d <-- needs to be @d

item.title: By: Thomas Pullen
item.dc:creator: Thomas Pullen
item.content:encoded:
Denis, have you tested this on SQL Server 2012? I got a problem with sysmail_delete_log_sp. I ran:-

DECLARE @d DATETIME

SET @d = DATEADD(dd, -14, GETDATE())

EXEC msdb.dbo.sysmail_delete_log_sp @logged_before = d

and got

Msg 8114, Level 16, State 5, Procedure sysmail_delete_log_sp, Line 0
Error converting data type nvarchar to datetime.

I haven’t investigated fully yet.

item.title: By: alzdba
item.dc:creator: alzdba
item.content:encoded:
Nice article.
We also clean up all mail items and logs older than 1 month.
This way the data-responsible has had a time frame of month to handle his failed dbmail stuff.
After that, we consider this data is no longer useful, so the cleanup sqlagent job kicks in ðŸ™‚
